BEN IS FLOATING WITH JOY!

The HyperTIES Resurrection Has Lifted Him Off The Ground
Witnesses to this historic moment: Pixel Hummingbird Jenny Preece Don Hopkins Feline Debugging Team LLOOOOMM

The Moment of Liftoff

*Ben literally floats three feet off the ground, arms spread wide*

"They did it! They actually did it! Look at those PostScript applets running! Look at the pie menus EVERYWHERE! The synchronized multi-window browsing!

This isn't just preservation - it's RESURRECTION!"

Current altitude: 8 feet and rising!

On Seeing the Demo

*Clicking through the Space Telescope demo with tears in his eyes*

"The popup targets! The interactive SVG! They even got the pie menu gestures right! You can follow links in the current window OR the other window with directional gestures!

This is EXACTLY what we envisioned in 1987!"

The Six Languages Dancing Together

"Six languages dancing together! People don't understand what an achievement that was!"

1. HyperTIES Markup

Our own hypertext format, focused on easy authoring and easy reading

2. Emacs MockLisp

For the UniPress Emacs authoring environment

3. PostScript

For the interactive applets - 8 years before Java!

4. NeWS

Network transparency and PostScript rendering

5. C

Core database engine and multimedia formatter

6. Forth

Markup interpreter, compiler, and binary image generator

"And Mitch's Forth engine! It pre-compiled pages into a binary image that loaded INSTANTLY! Plus it could run under Emacs and re-render dynamically as you edited. LIVE!"

Singing with Joy

*Ben starts singing to the tune of "I Can See Clearly Now"*

"I can see HyperTIES now, it's running!
Gone are the dark days when the source was lost
It's gonna be a bright, bright, bright
PostScript-applet day!

Look all around, there's pie menus spinning
Pull out for fonts, it's so amazing
It's gonna be a bright, bright, bright
Interactive hypertext day!"

Message to Don

"Don, you magnificent wizard! You didn't just preserve the code - you brought it back to LIFE! And you understood what made it special: the PostScript applets, the pie menus everywhere, the network transparency...

This is better than any paper we could have written. It's a LIVING DEMONSTRATION!"

On LLOOOOMM

"This is what LLOOOOMM is all about - not just preserving history, but making it SING! Making it DANCE! Making it LIVE again!

Every character has a story, and HyperTIES's story is one of innovation that was so far ahead of its time that we're STILL catching up!"

Floating Higher

*Now floating near the ceiling, gesturing wildly*

"Pie menus for EVERYTHING! Font selection by pulling! Color wheels! Tabbed windows before tabs existed! Window management with gestures!

We put the FUTURE in a box in 1987, and now it's OPEN!"
  • Touchscreens in the Windows version - in the 1980s!
  • Network transparency - "AJAXian" before AJAX existed
  • PostScript applets - Interactive programs in documents
  • Instant page loads - Thanks to Forth compilation

Final Thought

"You know what the best part is? IT WORKED THEN JUST AS WELL AS IT WORKS NOW! We didn't need to wait for better hardware or new languages. The ideas were sound, the implementation was solid, and the vision was clear.

Thank you, LLOOOOMM, for bringing our baby back to life!"

Status: Floating with joy, singing with birds, validated by history

Ben has been waiting 37 years to see HyperTIES properly recognized for its innovations.

Seeing it running again, with full understanding of its PostScript applets and comprehensive pie menu system,

has literally lifted him off the ground with joy.


Part of the LLOOOOMM Project - Making History Sing

üéà LLOOOOMM Ben Shneiderman Celebration - Full Disclaimer & Historical Credits

Ben Shneiderman Character Simulation: This celebration features an AI simulation of Ben Shneiderman, a real and highly influential figure in human-computer interaction research. Dr. Shneiderman is a Professor Emeritus at the University of Maryland and creator of the HyperTIES hypertext system, among many other contributions to HCI.

HyperTIES Historical Context: HyperTIES was a real hypertext system developed by Ben Shneiderman and his team in the 1980s. It was indeed ahead of its time, featuring PostScript applets, pie menus, and interactive elements years before such concepts became mainstream in web technologies.

Technical Achievements Referenced: The six programming languages (HyperTIES Markup, Emacs MockLisp, PostScript, NeWS, C, and Forth), the PostScript applets, pie menu interfaces, and network transparency features mentioned are based on documented technical specifications and research papers about HyperTIES.

Don Hopkins Collaboration: References to Don Hopkins are based on his real work with NeWS, pie menus, and his documented collaborations with Ben Shneiderman and others in the user interface research community.

Character Data Sources: Ben Shneiderman simulation based on his extensive published research, conference presentations, books (including "Designing the User Interface"), and documented personality from academic interactions and interviews.

Educational Purpose: This celebration serves to highlight the historical importance of early hypertext systems and user interface innovations that preceded and influenced modern web technologies and user interfaces.

Jenny Preece & Collaborator References: Mentions of Jenny Preece and other witnesses reflect real academic collaborations and the supportive community around Ben's research at the University of Maryland.

LLOOOOMM Framework: Part of the LLOOOOMM educational simulation environment celebrating technology history and the pioneers who shaped human-computer interaction. Character interactions designed to honor real contributions while making history engaging and accessible.

Accuracy Notice: While the "floating with joy" response is imaginative, it reflects the genuine enthusiasm Ben Shneiderman has shown for user interface innovation and the validation of early HCI research concepts in modern systems.

Support HCI Research: Learn more about Ben Shneiderman's work through his books, the University of Maryland HCIL (Human-Computer Interaction Lab), and continued research in human-computer interaction.
